segments.text: And what's your specialty in political science?
Public administration, which is... What's your field?
Geography.
Well, it's a long story.
I'll turn this off in a minute, and then I'll tell you all mine.
Well, the reason I ask what your field is, pub ed is kind of a...
It's a hybrid.
On the one hand, it's a kind of intellectual activity with...
epistemological concerns, you know, and philosophical concerns.
And then there's a great deal of grubby how-to kind of thing.
And so it's not a specialty that turns undergraduate or graduate students on, you know.
And so I always feel a bit apologetic for it, you know, because there's so much more exciting things, so many more exciting things to study in political science than I thought I had.
But somehow it was impressed on me very early that...

One of the fields they always need people in in public political science is pub ad, and I suppose as a result of employment experience, all this kind of thing, I'd always been kind of practically argumentative.
So this would explain that.
I suppose if I had that to do over again, I could be assured of a job, I would
have as my specialty normative political theory, because here you read all the good literature, you have sexy things to talk about.
But at that time, there just was no demand for people to teach normative theory.
Well, why political science?
Can you think of any reason why you got involved in that?
Well, I've always liked history.
I've read a great deal of history.
I like literature.
I'm an undergraduate minor.
I have an undergraduate minor in English literature and more in economics, major political science.
I've always liked to read.
And I think it's just probably similar to hundreds of thousands, perhaps, who were turned on by a professor.
And in this case, the professor was not particularly charismatic.
Certainly not a dynamic speaker or a magnetic personality, very matter-of-factly, but he interested me in subject matter, and it was sort of a cumulative process.
You know, I got interested in it and would take more of it, got more interested in it.
And Utah State, where I finished my undergraduate work, had a very small political science department.
I think there were only three people, but they were first-rate as teachers and as researchers.
And it was just a very happy experience, and the same thing carried through my entire graduate experience.
So it was just, you know, a fortuitous series of events.
It was when you finished your doctorate that you went to Peru?
No, I taught for, I got my first teaching job at Colorado College in Colorado Springs, and I taught there from 62 until 67.
When I went to Peru, and I came back to the college, and then left in 68.
But I had taught for five years.
And came here?
Did you come here?
No, it's long story.
I resigned in 68 from Colorado College.
I went to the University of Denver for two years.
I went to Memphis State University for two years, and then I came here.
Don't ask me why, because it's terribly self-seeking.
You know, a perfect opportunity.
And you've been here for?
I came here in September.
In this city?
Yes, this is my first.
I completed my first.
And you were first in Mexico, in Juarez, after coming here.
Yes, I was interviewed here a year ago, January, and Ed took me over to Corona.
It was the first time, basically.
I've been back often, and Polly and I want to go down, and I've almost convinced myself that I am going to go to La Veracruz.
I know I have family there.
But I keep dragging my feet.
I can't really explain why.
You know, I make up all sorts of convenient excuses that, you know, I have to work this summer, or Bobby's got to go to camp.
At least I knew why I'm reluctant to go back.
That's interesting.
How did you react to Juarez?
Very well, very well.
I was delighted by the Spanish, you know, and the culture.
I was used to the poverty already as a result of being in South America.
And this is just the condition, the fact of life.
I'm hauled by it.
There's very little I can do about it.
The poverty, the extremes of wealth.
But I don't think the stereotypic response of being appalled by the dirt, this kind of thing, I suppose it's part of my culture.
I am delighted to be here.
It's a delight to go to the Union and hear Spanish spoken.
delightful community to speak Spanish with my students, of the diet.
Maybe this is why I feel a little strong compulsion to get to Mexico, in the sense of going down, because so much of it is here.
What is your perception of Mexico?
Do you think of it as a relatively dynamic country right now?
What do you feel about the revolution?
Do you think it... Yeah, I think that as far as I'm concerned, it's the first genuine social revolution that we've ever seen.
even more genuine than French, because they substituted one regime with another dictatorship.
I think that it's really the unfortunate thing about the Mexican Revolution is that it happened in a small country.
It was ultimately powerless.
And it's gotten no press, which is worse than a bad press, and therefore nobody knows about it.
And so to this extent, I think that Mexico's revolution as a contribution has been overlooked.
And it's only been recently with the scholarship of Womack, for example, people are regarding the Mexican revolution seriously.
But even in South America, they don't think of the Mexican revolution as a model.
They think of Castro's revolution as a model.
It's very interesting.
My previous students, anyhow.
And this is why I say I think they've got no press as opposed to a bad press or a good press.
But I'm very prideful of the Mexican Revolution, because it was, in my job, the first genuine social revolution.
And I'm very prideful of the heroes that emerged.
I think a great deal of this is romanticizing.
But this is a latter-day acquisition.
I think not until I was about 35 or 36 did I really feel confident enough to face up to my own background in America.
I'm not really apologetic for it.
I can't justify it.
But I do try to reason with myself and say it's understandable, given the conditions under which you were brought up, to react in this way.
Sort of just make the whole thing invisible.
But do you have any sense of the amount of, say, socioeconomic progress made in Mexico, say, in the last 15 or 20 years?
This would be intellectual, on my part, rather than experiential firsthand.
And I think that there is considerable in that.
There isn't the starvation that my mother used to talk about, except for the Indians, perhaps, in isolated areas.
There's not the brutalization that there was.
The Urales, for example, don't kill half the countryside at will.
without retribution.
So I think in this sense, there's been a quantum leap.
Now, if you measure the advances they've made, say, compared to the advances that the industrialized nations of the North made, well, they're still dragging behind.
Well, do you think of Mexico as being essentially an urban industrial nation or approaching that point?
I think of it as being mixed.
I wish I could label it in one of Rob Stout's seven stages, but I don't.
I think that it is industrialized in the key industries, petroleum, railroad, what else, mining.
But I also see a great deal of agriculture providing the livelihood for thousands of people.
And so to that extent, I think that it's still approaching the stage of industrialization in the modern Western American, Japanese sense of the word.
But I think that...
that there has been a demonstrable increase in the quantity and quality of life.
I was reading something, I can't remember where, just in the past week, that we really don't have a regular starvation in the world anymore, with the exception of India, perhaps.

But the person was arguing that instead of being pessimistic and saying we're really in very bad shape, we should face up to the fact that we don't have the families, we don't have the scourges of the past,
We've really come a long way in the sense of medical advances, dietary advances.
And so if you use this as an index, it would seem that Mexico would qualify as making this sort of quantum jump.
I can't give an example firsthand.
But I get the idea that while people have to work very hard in Mexico, and that their diet isn't what it might be, this is still better
than the misery that was there when my parents were growing up there, when people would starve to death.
What about the class system?
To what extent do you think of Mexico as being a nation with a strong middle class?
I don't think it's got a strong middle class.
I think it's got a strong upper class, even though I have a colleague in the department who is Mexican national who denies this and says, well, this is my imagination.

No, I don't know whether this, my reaction comes from my reading of Mexico, my experience in South America, but I have a feeling that in the countries I've been in Mexico, which we just did, or Mexico and Peru, is that there's a very, very strong upper class orientation in the sense that the upper class dictates morals, mores, manners.
Would you compare Mexico with Peru in this sense?
Not in this sense, because Peru, at the time I was there,
Now, you've got to remember that Alvarado has been there since, and he's changed things quite a bit.
I said Alvarado, I meant Velazquez in Peru.
And so there may be a diminution or dilution of the class structure since Alvarado was there just five years ago.
But I still see very strong overtones of this.
For example, in restaurants in Mexico, I see the...
In Juarez.
Juarez, yes.
I think here at El Paso, you know, I see a very patronizing attitude on the part of educated Mexicans to their compatriots, you know, who are clerics, mediums, whatever.
So this is what I'm basing my impression on.
And I feel a certain amount of this towards me.
Now, I have a colleague here, his name is Leonardo.
And as you can imagine, we chat frequently about these things.
And one of the things we noted is
that there is a tendency on the part of Mexicans to look down on Mexican-Americans who are in Mexico, even if the Mexican-Americans are professional, as he and I are.
And there's Nstor Valencia, who is a man in local government.
He's known the same thing.

And I think these impressions which we have experienced have convinced us that although you can't perhaps quantify this in an empirical study, that there is a definite class, upper class bias in Mexico, in my experience,

which I think is acting as a governor, inhibitor, or retarder of the revolution to the extent that they see their own purpose as being endangered by too much democratization or too much redistribution of wealth.
Have you ever run into many Mexican nationals who talk of themselves as clase media and who take tremendous pride in being middle class?
You haven't encountered much of this.
No, because I think that the people who are professionals still consider themselves members of the Catholic media, but members of the upper class.
Jose Luis, for example.
He may be, indeed, upper class.
You would agree with Richard Adams, one of my old professors.
He just says the upper class keeps getting bigger, in effect.
Yeah, that's right.
That's essentially...
They co-opt.
You see, the middle class,
are supposed to be defined as the mechanic, automobile mechanic, you see, who we would consider working class.
Because there's a voluntary co-optation process at work, if I can call it that.
It was the guy who becomes a ,, a ,, an intellectual, a journalist.
The minute they get the titulo, they become members of the upper class, you see, rather than members of the group.
Now, we might define them on our standards in terms of income as middle class, but they consider the job, in my judgment,
as well as the upper class.
Jose Luis is a good example.
And this is supported by what you know from this particular area.
Yeah, I would think so, yeah.
I'm curious.
You know what I'd like for you to do?
Professor, when you do go to Mexico, and I hope you go for a long enough time to have it soak in, like a month or two, I'd like for you to keep a diary.
A very impressionistic diary, because I think it could be a very fascinating thing.
I'm sure, yeah.
I've done diaries, you know, from time to time.
I suppose like most people who start a diary, they let them lapse very, very soon.
I've not thought about it.
You seem to have a very different image of Mexico.
What was that?
Oh, and then after that, after I'd already paid my fees, I put my card packet over to turn it in.
The dear little lady sitting there collecting the card packet says, oh, well, you'll have to take it over to housing and get your housing card stamped before I can take your card packet.
I've already paid my fees.
She says, yes, but you have to go to housing.
So I had to go to housing.
And for the umpteenth year in time, I have the permission to be on campus.
One o'clock.
I'm only making beds this morning.
Yes.
Yes.
You want to put it on?
No, not that hand.
That is crazy.
Some guy had it.
I don't remember.
What's the towel doing on the tape recorder?
What?
What?
Where's the little plug?
